1 In a computer science department, a student club can be formed with either 10 
members from the first year or 8 members from second year or 6 from third year or 
4 from final year. What is the minimum no. of students we have to choose randomly 
from department to ensure that a student club is formed? 
CO2 1 
2 A computation is divided among three processors that can only handle small 
numbers: 
 Processor 1 computes results mod 13 
 Processor 2 computes results mod 17 
 Processor 3 computes results mod 19 
The partial results for some computation are 9, 4, and 11 respectively. 
 
(a) Use CRT to reconstruct the overall result mod 13 × 17 × 19. 
 
(b) Discuss one real-world scenario (e.g., cryptography or data storage) where this 
approach improves efficiency. 
 
CO2 1 
3 Three planets revolve around a star with orbital periods of 15, 20, and 28 years 
respectively. 
 
 Use the least common multiple and CRT to determine after how many years all 
three will align again. 
 
CO2 1 
4 Suppose a server uses a 10-digit hash to label uploaded files. If 1 million files are 
uploaded, prove using the Pigeonhole Principle that at least two files share a hash 
value. 
 
CO2 1 
5 Two groups of students, one with 48 members and the other with 64 members, are 
to be organized into the largest possible equal-sized teams. Each team should have 
students from only one group. What is the largest number of students that can be 
in each team? 
CO2 1

7 Four radio towers are placed at the corners of a square and one in the center. 
Each tower must be assigned a frequency such that adjacent towers do not share 
the same frequency. 
 
(a) Model this as a graph coloring problem. 
(b) Apply the Welch–Powell algorithm to find the chromatic number. 
(c) Suggest a real-world meaning of the chromatic number in communication 
systems.

(a) Construct a graph of the locations. 
(b) Determine whether it has a Hamiltonian cycle. 
(c) Suggest how this could help plan a guided tour or robot navigation route.
